Description: Limestone panel from a tomb-relief: this panel bears two representations of Shery: in the upper, he is shown stepping forward; in the lower, he is seated and holds a staff of office. The text includes a cartouche. It is carved in good low relief. The surface is much weathered and is flaking through the action of salt. No colour remains.
Curator's comments: The panel, complete apart from the top, originally formed, probably, the reveal of a doorway. The tomb of Shery is interesting because its inscriptions mention the shadowy Second Dynasty King Sened whose mortuary service, from the evidence of this tomb, seems to have continued into the Fourth Dynasty. Bibliography: B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' III (2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 490.
Bibliographic references: Scott-Moncrieff 1911 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 1. (Pl.3)
James 1961 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc. Part 1 (pl.13)
Condition: Fair (incomplete). The surface is much weathered and is flaking through the action of salt.
Acquisition name: Purchased through: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
